channel.title: Daily Feed (Last 48 Hours, Updated 9 AM BD)
channel.description: Daily Feed (Last 48 Hours, Updated 9 AM BD) generated by script

item.title: Will Trump Go to War With Iran?
item.description: The scale of the U.S. military buildup signals that strikes are likely.

item.title: Trump’s Board of Peace Takes on Gaza
item.description: During its first day in action, nine members of the board agreed to pledge a total of $7 billion toward relief for the war-torn enclave.

item.title: Trump Kicks Off First Board of Peace Meeting on Gaza
item.description: During its first day in action, nine members of the board agreed to pledge a total of $7 billion toward relief for the war-torn enclave.

item.title: How Chinese Espionage Eroded U.S. Power
item.description: A conversation with the authors of “The Great Heist” on Beijing’s spycraft—and what can be done about it.

item.title: How to Actually Fix Foreign Aid
item.description: We can’t turn back the clock on USAID. But we can decide what comes next.

item.title: The moment of reckoning between America and Iran
item.description: Donald Trump must soon choose whether to attack Iran or beat a humiliating retreat

item.title: Move over, Best Ranger; the Army’s looking for the best drone pilots
item.description: The Huntsville competition is also meant to shape the selection and training of unmanned systems operators.

item.title: Trump’s U.S. Mining Push Has a Big Problem
item.description: The country may not have the workforce to power a minerals renaissance.

item.title: Cyber responses will be ‘linked to adversary actions,’ involve industry: White House
item.description: New national cyber strategy, expected last month, will be released “soon."

item.title: Inside Iran’s Post-Massacre Power Struggle
item.description: The state has consolidated by purging its connections with the public.

item.title: Global Cooperation in a Time of Geopolitical Disruption
item.description: With the rules-based international order breaking down, “minilateralism” might offer a means of devising new ideas – in particular, for scalable interventions that tangibly improve people’s lives. Without interventions that highlight the benefits of international engagement, broad-based cooperation will remain a hard sell.

item.title: A psychedelic medicine performs well against depression
item.description: Regulators are now mulling the results of the late-stage trial

item.title: Quantum Computing Could Fix AI’s Sustainability Problem
item.description: As generative AI pushes power grids to their limits, the industry largely favors incremental measures that fail to address underlying issues. The path toward sustainable AI lies in combining quantum computing with energy-efficient application design.

item.title: The Seven Pillars of Populist Foreign Policy
item.description: To understand Trump’s approach to the world, look at the leaders he resembles.

item.title: The D Brief: Buildup around Iran; More Somalia strikes; SOUTHCOM in Venezuela; JAG in trouble; And a bit more.
MAGA’s Approach to Europe Hasn’t Changed
item.description: Although the speech that US Secretary of State Marco Rubio delivered to this year’s Munich Security Conference was softer in tone than the one that Vice President JD Vance gave last year, the Europe he celebrated was that of the ethno-nationalist far right. Europe is on its own, and it must start acting like it.

item.title: Forecasting the BNP’s Diplomacy in South Asia and Beyond
item.description: Already, Tarique Rahman has made clear that Bangladesh’s interests would guide foreign policy. China, India, and the United States are recalibrating their approaches accordingly.

item.title: Pakistan’s Search for Strategic Flexibility in South Asia
item.description: With discussions on a possible new, flexible, regional platform with Turkiye and Saudi Arabia, Pakistan is seeking to build backup security channels in a dynamic region.

item.title: The Hypocrisy of Art Basel Qatar
item.description: The world’s cultural elite gathered in Doha to celebrate values denied by their host nation.

item.title: How to improve American legislators’ lot
item.description: Doing so would be good for members of Congress, and for democracy

item.title: Saudi Arabia and the Emirates must resolve their own differences
item.description: America’s neglect is allowing an unwelcome tension to fester between two of its allies

item.title: Different ideas about faith are dividing Republicans over Israel
item.description: The Republicans’ internal fight could prove more toxic than the Democrats’

item.title: The Trump administration wants to put antifa on trial
item.description: A case in Texas offers an opportunity to do so

item.title: Donald Trump’s policies are reshaping American health care
item.description: And the consequences will ripple through both health and politics

item.title: Could the next big gambling destination be in the Gulf?
item.description: The UAE hopes to emulate Las Vegas and Macau

item.title: Giorgio Armani’s bizarre will has caused a rift at his fashion label
item.description: The choices its new leaders make could shape the future of Italian luxury

item.title: The case for workplace inefficiency
item.description: Stop optimising. Start pronking

item.title: Peru ousts a president under the shadow of Chinese meddling
item.description: José Jerí was the country’s eighth president in a decade.

item.title: Could One Nation soon become Australia’s most popular party?
item.description: The anti-immigrant party is dragging the Liberals rightward as well

item.title: A nasty spate of shark attacks in the Sydney area
item.description: Is global warming to blame?

item.title: Can Bangladesh’s old guard build a new democracy?
item.description: The first real election since 2008 is won by a prodigal son

item.title: China now fills the world’s luxury hampers
item.description: It is a leading producer of caviar, foie gras and truffles

item.title: The weekly cartoon
Politics
Business
Serbia’s protesters learn it’s hard to topple a president
item.description: President Aleksandar Vucic is trying to outlast fury over corruption

item.title: How Germany fell out of love with China
item.description: Chinese industry is beating Germany at its own game. Cue panic

item.title: Poles have split and soured on America
item.description: Donald Trump is exhausting goodwill in Europe’s most pro-American country

item.title: The global triumph of Nigerian fashion
item.description: Its flamboyant styles are gracing red carpets and going viral on TikTok

item.title: A book fair in Damascus is a window on the new Syria
item.description: But many worry it will not stay open for long

item.title: Libya has no good options for leaders
item.description: Mourning at the death of a man indicted for crimes against humanity highlights Libya’s bleakness

item.title: Can India Power the AI Dream?
item.description: The country has rushed to embrace artificial intelligence. Its impacts on jobs, the electrical grid, and water availability need to be taken into account.

item.title: China’s Military Purges Won’t Change Its Taiwan Calculus
item.description: The purges carry real implications for China’s domestic politics and short-term military readiness, but their relevance to Beijing’s Taiwan policy is limited.

item.title: Ex-President Yoon Given Life Sentence for Insurrection
item.description: The court’s recognition of Yoon as a rebellion leader necessitates an expedited final ruling to permanently root out martial law remnants.

item.title: The Global Green Financial Divide Is Growing
item.description: By repealing the "endangerment finding" that required US authorities to consider the societal costs of greenhouse-gas emissions, the Trump administration has further reduced the regulatory burden on US banks relative to their peers. For advocates of international competition on a level playing field, it is an unwelcome change.

item.title: How four years of war have changed Russia
item.description: The fighting in Ukraine has reshaped everyday life

item.title: India is in the midst of a data-centre investment boom
item.description: Money is flowing into the country, but the benefits may prove temporary

item.title: The EU is thrashing out a more muscular set of economic policies
item.description: The bloc is done playing nicely

item.title: Did America’s war on poverty fail?
item.description: Deprivation has fallen dramatically—but not necessarily because of the welfare state

item.title: Geopolitical Jockeying in Nepal Ahead of March General Elections
item.description: The post-election climate in Nepal looks particularly harsh for China, as Nepal’s major communist forces are not expected to do well in the elections.

item.title: Dead or Alive, Imran Khan Puts Pakistan’s General Munir in a Catch-22 Situation
item.description: In trying to contain Khan, the system may be unintentionally shaping the very legend it fears.

item.title: Why the IMF’s newest report finds that the yuan is undervalued
item.description: It says the currency is 16% cheaper than it should be

item.title: Prediction markets are rife with insider betting
item.description: That does not mean regulators should stamp it out

item.title: Vladimir Putin is caught in a vice of his own making
item.description: Russia’s president cannot win the war, but fears peace

item.title: Don’t go after the rich to fix broken budgets
item.description: It will not work, and is wrong in principle

item.title: Superpower Europe
item.description: Europe may be a different kind of superpower, given the extent to which it prioritizes values, rules, and multilateralism over sheer might. But it is a superpower nonetheless, and it is increasingly pursuing investments and reforms that will make it not only unassailable but also widely attractive in a dangerous world.

item.title: Boeing moves its defense HQ back to St. Louis
item.description: The aerospace giant’s global headquarters will remain in Arlington, Va.

item.title: Shipwrecks, Sham Papers and False Flags: Tracking the Company Behind It All
item.description:
A shipwreck in India, an ammunition seizure in Senegal, and a raid on an oil tanker in Malaysia – all three incidents involve ageing vessels, operating with false papers and one recurring figure: Captain Suniel Kumar Sharma. For over a decade, Sharma has been condemned by the governments of Dominica, Guyana, Samoa, the Federated States […]

The post Shipwrecks, Sham Papers and False Flags: Tracking the Company Behind It All appeared first on bellingcat.

item.title: Energy Dominance With Chinese Characteristics
item.description: Why Beijing holds the power in the century ahead.

item.title: Southeast Asia and the Rohingya Militant Threat
item.description: The refugee crisis in Bangladesh is steadily metastasizing into a transnational ecosystem of criminality, militancy, and corruption.

item.title: Thailand Wants to Bring Myanmar Back Into ASEAN, Foreign Minister Says
item.description: After a meeting with his junta counterpart, Sihasak Phuangketkeow said that Thailand wanted to be a "bridge" connecting Myanmar back to the regional community.

item.title: 3 Southeast Asian Leaders Arrive in Washington for ‘Board of Peace’ Summit
item.description: Indonesia, Vietnam, and Cambodia each have their reasons for taking part in President Donald Trump's initiative, but most of the region remains cautious.

item.title: Control, Alt, Influence: the Potential for US Cyber Operations in Iran
item.description: Speculation is mounting over how the US will act if diplomacy fails and a deal with Iran to remove the country’s nuclear capability collapses. As options are debated, ‘cyber’ remains ever elusive.

item.title: RUSI Reflects: Ukraine’s Remarkable Resilience After Four Years of War
item.description: Ukraine has demonstrated remarkable resilience across four years of conflict with Russia, though it faces challenges maintaining its society and military cohesion.

item.title: That irritating feeling that France was right
item.description: Donald Trump’s America makes Gaullism respectable again

item.title: Why Did Philippine VP Sara Duterte Declare Her Presidential Candidacy?
item.description: Duterte’s early declaration for the 2028 presidential election is inseparable from her ongoing feud with President Ferdinand Marcos Jr.

item.title: Lai’s Tougher Stance on Transnational Repression Has Taiwan’s Hong Kongers Optimistic
item.description: After 2019, Taiwan saw an influx of political refugees from Hong Kong. But even self-exile didn't guarantee safety.
